You want to blindly serve whatever you're holding, and otherwise proxy the backend.
Depends on how complex your queries are
There's no such thing as a one-size-fits-all solution when it comes to working with data.
So when you say "cache json" I think varnish.
When you say "query remote data" I think "how much data? How much querying?"
If it's not a lot, and not complex, use redis, Otherwise use something like mongo. If it's too much postgres. If it's WAY too much, work out something with hadoop
Have an async task running that fetches data from them the entire time
Or how often it changes, anyway
Well if it's that much mongo is still fine
redis might be less logical then
From what I've seen, redis makes most sense for small amounts of data that has to be quickly accessible
anyway... If you go around with over 100k of records I'd consider using postgres, unless you do little to no filtering
Just treat it as local data.
And make sure you have that local data elsewhere
You can focus on using the data without worrying where it's from
and on the other end, make sure you have that data.
Perhaps they have the option to dump their data
Or push all of it in a nicer format
But it makes thinking about it a lot easier.
Make life easy. Because in a year you're going to want to change stuff anyway. No matter how perfectly complex you make it now.
The only thing you can really do, is separate concerns so it'll be easier to swap out later.
But you're going to have to get your hands dirty regardless of the solution you pick
It allows you to see a lot more
Which at some point is the next step you might be taking.
Having knowledge on a ton of stuff helps.
